newsitem.title: UK: US court reduces damages, GKN still appeals.
newsitem.headline: US court reduces damages, GKN still appeals.

text.p: A U.S. court has reduced damages awarded against Britain's GKN Plc in a case concerning a U.S. subsidiary but the engineering giant on Friday said that it was still appealing against the ruling.

The company said the U.S. district court in Charlotte, North Carolina, reduced damages against GKN's Meineke Discount Muffler Shops to $390 million from $600 million -- the largest commercial damages ever to be awarded against a British company in the United States.

The award had been in favour of Meineke's 2,500 U.S. franchises, who alleged that the auto-muffler retailer had mishandled and misappropriated millions of dollars charged to the franchisees for advertising. They first brought the case against GKN in December 1993.
GKN said in a statement it has "very strong substantive and procedural grounds for appeal". The appeal process is expected to take around 18 months.
Shares in GKN jumped on the news and at 1000 GMT stood 21 pence higher at 10.05-1/2 pounds, their highest since late March and extending a rally from April 24's 13-month low of 905 pence.

"The court ruling is exactly as anticipated," said Robert Speed, analyst at Henderson Crosthwaite. "Why the stock is up on what is effectively just purely a maintenance of the status quo, I'm not sure."
Speed said the rally in defence stocks generally "could well have something to do with (GKN's) share price movement".
GKN was seen benefiting from a report in the Independent newspaper that the UK government would not block sales of military equipment to Indonesia.
Indonesian orders include armoured vehicles made by GKN.
The newspaper reported that Foreign Office sources had said export licences granted in December would not be revoked, easing concerns of a general clampdown on military exports.
News of the damages award sent GKN shares down sharply when first announced in December and it suffered a setback last week on renewed concerns about legal action from Meineke franchisees.
At last week's annual meeting one franchisee said a group of franchisees excluded from GKN's legal settlement were preparing to file a lawsuit to be re-included in the class action.
"That is unaltered by this decision," said Speed.
Just as GKN has been freed by the court ruling to launch an appeal against the overall judgement, so these franchisees, who signed waivers, could file a claim, he added.

In March, a federal judge in Charlotte -- the headquarters of Meineke -- tripled compensatory damages of $197 million awarded in December by a jury that found Meineke had committed breach of contract, negligence and fraud.
GKN said the reduced figure confirms the previous ruling and is within the 270 million pounds provision it made in its 1996 accounts to cover the judgement, interests and costs.
"(This ruling) does not shut the door (on the issue) because clearly GKN is pursuing an appeal," Speed pointed out.
